I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the National Capital Region Planning Board (NCRPB), to 
be guaranteed by the Government of India, for the National Capital Region Urban Infrastructure 
Financing Facility.  
 
2.  The proposed MFF to NCRPB1 will establish the facility, which will develop regional and 
city-specific urban infrastructure in India's National Capital Region (NCR) based on priorities set 
by the Regional Plan 2021. In addition, the facility's implementation support will enable NCRPB 
and various subborrowers to scale up effective and sustainable urban infrastructure services in 
the NCR. 2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE FACILITY 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The Indian economy has emerged as one of the fastest-growing world economies,3 and 
this growth is likely to continue at a high rate.4 Urban areas in India are experiencing higher 
population  growth  rates,  among  others,  due  to  greater  economic  opportunities. 5  Urban 
infrastructure  and  basic  services  are  under  stress  due  to  increasing  demand  from  the 
burgeoning urban population. However, by nature, urban infrastructure is complex and more 
difficult to scale up than other infrastructure.6 Cities are unable to cope with the increasing 
demand because of weak municipal financial and institutional capacities. While tariffs for basic 
urban services are low, the public-good nature of urban infrastructure makes a significant 
portion of urban basic services unsuited to having user fees.7 The perceived high and real risks 
of  urban  infrastructure  investments  make  private  investors  wary.  Recognizing  the  binding 
constraints on scaling up urban infrastructure, the Government of India launched a reform-linked 
urban investment program in December 2005, the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal 
Mission (JNNURM), to address some of the challenges emerging from rapid urbanization.8  
 
4.  The summary sector assessment (footnote 7) gives a background to the generic and 
specific issues facing urban infrastructure development in India’s NCR. Among other things, 
there is a need for a paradigm shift in the way urban infrastructure is planned and executed. 
From  being  city-centric,  urban  infrastructure  needs  to  have  a  regional  approach  that 
encompasses both surrounding rural areas as well as other smaller towns. City-centric urban

infrastructure  planning  tends  to  be  a  reactive  approach,  responding  to  in-migration  and 
infrastructure crises in a knee-jerk manner. A regional planning approach is more proactive, 
enabling systematic and inclusive urbanization, and sustainable economic growth.9 A regional 
approach has the potential to guide planned development of urban areas which are free of the 
negative aspects of recently witnessed rapid urbanization—environmental degradation, traffic 
jams,  burgeoning  slums,  non-inclusive  growth,  and  increased  greenhouse  gas  emissions. 
Moreover,  given  the  weak  return  on  investment  that  has  long  payback  period,  urban 
infrastructure financing needs debt with competitive interest rates and longer tenures to make 
urban  infrastructure  projects  bankable.  This  will  generate  interest  among  sponsors 
(subborrowers) and result in debt-based project financing, as against the largely grant-driven 
urban infrastructure culture that currently exists. 
 
5.  NCRPB is a regional planner and financier of the NCR, which is one of the fastest-
growing urban agglomerate regions in India. NCRPB's Regional Plan 2021 envisages massive 
scaling up of urban infrastructure investments in the NCR. However, due to domestic debt 
market limitations, the tenure that NCRPB is able to currently offer is a maximum of 10 years. In 
addition, due to weak project development and project management capacities in a number of 
NCRPB's subborrowers, inadequate numbers of urban infrastructure projects are generated, 
and there are systemic weaknesses in project execution. Before weak urban infrastructure 
becomes a binding constraint on the rapid pace of economic growth in the NCR, NCRPB needs 
to enable the scaling up of urban infrastructure by implementing the priorities of Regional Plan 
2021. NCRPB can accelerate the scaling-up process of urban development by (i) providing 
longer-tenure low-cost debt; (ii) providing implementation support for subborrowers (borrowers 
of NCRPB) in urban planning, project development, and project implementation; (iii) identifying 
and supporting structuring of bankable projects and enabling private sector investments; and 
(iv) improving urban basic service provision by, among other things, encouraging partnership 
with the private sector. Adequate incentives need to be provided by NCRPB to motivate cities 
and state government entities to undertake public health and environmental urban infrastructure 
projects  that  can  mitigate  greenhouse  gas  emissions,  ensure  geographic  and  sector 
inclusiveness, and introduce private sector efficiencies. The remaining details of the rationale 
are discussed further in this section as well as in the summary sector assessment and Schedule 
1 of the framework financing agreement.10 
 
6.  National Capital Region and counter magnet areas. The NCR is a 33,578 square 
kilometer area covering Delhi and subregions of the states of Haryana, Rajasthan, and Uttar 
Pradesh. In addition to Delhi the NCR consists of nine districts of Haryana (Faridabad, Gurgaon, 
Jhajjar, Mewat, Palwal, Panipat, Rewari, Rohtak and Sonipat), one district of Rajasthan (Alwar 
district), and five districts of Uttar Pradesh (Baghpat, Bulandshahr, Gautam Buddha Nagar, 
Ghaziabad and Meerut). The population of the NCR is 37 million (urbanization level of 54% as 
per the 2001 census), and this is expected to increase to 64 million by 2021. In addition to the 
NCR,  NCRPB  supports  Gwalior  (Madhya  Pradesh),  Patiala  (Punjab),  Ambala  and  Hissar 
(Haryana), Dehradun (Uttarakhand), Kota (Rajasthan), and Kanpur and Bareilly (Uttar Pradesh) 
cities  as  part  of  the  counter  magnet  areas  (CMAs)  where  development  strategies  are 
implemented to ease the projected population pressure on the National Capital Territory of 
Delhi.

7.  Rapid economic growth in the NCR is likely to generate increased demand for drinking 
water, waste water management, and solid-waste management in the order of Rs230 billion, 
which excludes the demand for urban transport infrastructure in the NCR. While the National 
Capital  Territory  of  Delhi  is  making  rapid  progress  in  developing  urban  infrastructure,  the 
remaining portions of the NCR, especially the subregion administered by the government of 
Uttar  Pradesh,  are  still  lagging  in  infrastructure  resources.  Infrastructure  related  to  the 
environment and public health—water supply, sewerage, and solid waste—has been relatively 
neglected throughout the NCR in the past, and should be one of the key thrust areas. Analyses 
of  the  economies  of  states  and  cities  in  the  NCR  suggest  that  self-generated  funds  and 
technological  know-how  are  insufficient  to  provide  the  desired  rapid  growth  in  urban 
infrastructure.  
 
8.  The NCR's strength is that it continues to attract the largest share of foreign direct 
investment in India and efforts are under way to enhance this advantage by developing the 
Delhi–Mumbai corridor, inclusive of high-speed rail connectivity. In this context, the supply of 
urban infrastructure needs planning and financing to ensure that the regional impacts of growth 
are maximized to foster competitiveness and environmental sustainability. Since most of these 
infrastructure  demands  require  coordination,  a  regional  approach  is  needed  to  minimize 
geographic and functional fragmentation. This is one of the primary motivations for creating 
NCRPB and is the basis of the proposed NCRPB business plan and the proposed National 
Capital Region Urban Infrastructure Financing Facility.  
 
9.  National Capital Region Planning Board and the Regional Plan 2021. NCRPB came 
into being by virtue of the NCRPB Act, 1985 passed by the Parliament and duly confirmed by 
the legislatures of Haryana, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh. As a financier, NCRPB’s role is to 
facilitate the financing of the investments in the NCR. In pursuance of this NCRPB has provided 
loans of Rs64.6 billion to 239 projects as of 30 October 2009.11 Over the years there has been a 
shift  in  NCRPB's  focus  in  terms  of  diversifying  sector  allocation  of  resources  towards 
environmental infrastructure and connectivity. NCRPB is committed to increasing investments in 
lagging areas of the NCR, and has set up a project development fund in 2009 to achieve this 
objective as well as enhance access to capital markets by NCRPB and subborrowers.  
 
10.  In  2005  NCRPB  notified  the  Regional  Plan  2021,  with  focus  on  core  sectors  of 
transportation, power, water and sanitation, and solid waste, and an investment requirement of 
Rs1,937.5 billion.12 Regional Plan 2021 aims to facilitate growth and balanced development of 
the  NCR  by  providing  an  economic  base  in  the  identified  major  settlements  (metropolitan 
centers and regional centers) to (i) absorb economic development impulses of Delhi, (ii) develop 
efficient transport networks, (iii) develop physical infrastructure, (iv) enable rational land use 
patterns, and (v) improve the environment and quality of life. As inputs into the regional plan, 
NCRPB progressed substantially in developing the transport sector plan (2009) and the water 
supply plan (2009).13 The sector investment plans for sewerage and solid-waste management, 
including regional landfill sites, are under preparation. 
 
11.   While NCRPB has been financing investments, it is in the process of repositioning itself 
to achieve its scaled-up mandates. The basic vision of NCRPB is in terms of being a financier of 
relevance and planner of significance. This entails (i) serving as a planner of relevance for

(ii) moving away from  unlimited liability, administered credit pricing, and low leverage; and 
(iii) filling an institutional vacuum pertaining to urban infrastructure planning and development to 
address the unique challenges in scaling up urban infrastructure investments in the NCR and 
CMAs (schedule 1 of the framework financing agreement [footnote 10] and the summary sector 
assessment [footnote 7]). NCRPB needs to address the institutional aspects of its role to 
facilitate  infrastructure  financing  and  mitigate  specific  challenges  pertaining  to  urban 
infrastructure development in the NCR. Moreover, it is difficult for public institutions such as 
local municipalities and other urban local bodies alone to meet the demand for urban facilities. 
Thus, the need for successful public–private partnerships (PPPs) is indisputable if the regional 
plan  is  to  materialize  by  2021.  The  role  of  development  partners  in  urban  infrastructure 
development is limited in the NCR outside the National Capital Territory of Delhi. The Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will be the first development partner to support NCRPB. 14 ADB has 
provided technical assistance in the past few years to strengthen the capacities of NCRPB and 
its subborrowers.15 
 
12.  To  summarize,  the  facility  is  built  on  strong  rationale  that  includes  (i)  transforming 
NCRPB to more effectively meet the scaled-up mandates in line with the priorities of Regional 
Plan 2021; (ii) strengthening the ability of subborrowers to design and execute high-quality 
infrastructure; (iii) enabling private sector participation and PPPs in urban infrastructure and 
basic service provision; (iv) introducing best practices in infrastructure planning, execution, and 
operations;  and  (v)  enabling  geographic  and  sector  inclusiveness,  and  directing  more 
investments  into  public  health  and  environmental  urban  infrastructure.  Beyond  the  NCR, 
additional  development  benefits  are  expected  from  NCRPB's  successful  transformation 
(building on current strengths of NCRPB's unique regional planning and financing role) and 
strengthened capacities from the facility for proactive project development, structuring private 
sector participation (PSP) and PPPs, and project execution. It will emerge as an institutional 
model for emulation by other urban sector entities. The proposed facility incorporates lessons 
learnt (footnote 6), and is very much in line with ADB's Strategy 2020 as reflected in the India 
country partnership strategy for 2009–201216 as well as India's 11th Five Year Plan.17 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the facility is to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of 
urban residents in India's NCR and CMAs. The outcome of the facility is that urban residents in 
the intervention cities of the NCR and CMAs use improved growth-supporting and public health 
and environmental urban infrastructure services in accordance with the priorities of Regional 
Plan 2021. To this effect, the facility will support NCRPB in (i) leveraging its resources through a 
line of credit and other market access support services, and (ii) implementation support that will

C.  Outputs 
14.  There are three broad outputs of this facility: (i) creating high-quality urban public health 
and environmental infrastructure including water supply, sanitation, and waste management 
projects; (ii) creating high-quality regional and urban infrastructure that will support economic 
growth and include investments in regional connectivity and multimodal public transit systems, 
among other things; and (iii) providing implementation support for strengthening NCRPB and 
participating subborrowers' capacity to scale up urban infrastructure and improve basic urban 
services. The implementation support has the following subcomponents: (i) improving NCRPB's 
effectiveness to execute scaled-up infrastructure mandates; (ii) enabling inclusive and balanced 
geographic  and  sector  infrastructure;  (iii)  ensuring  infrastructure  projects  are  executed 
effectively; and (iv) enabling PSP in urban infrastructure development and urban basic service 
provision.18

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
20.  The indicative subprojects identified as part of the pipeline and those that would be 
financed are based on accepted national and international design standards, and the designs 
incorporate  least-cost  technical  options,  especially  water  supply  and  sewerage.  The  major 
codes are the Central Public Health Environmental Engineering Organization’s code for water 
                                                 
22 Financial Intermediary: Environmental and Social Management System Arrangement (Appendix 2).

8   
and sanitation, the Municipal Solid Waste Management Handling Rules 2000 for municipal solid 
waste, the Bureau of Indian Standards for structures, and the Indian Roads Congress codes for 
transport infrastructure. The pipeline of subprojects consists of public health and environmental 
services  (water,  waste  water,  and  growth-related  facilities),  transit  facilities  and  road 
infrastructure, and information-technology-enabled facilities as part of the transit facilities. The 
technologies are those that are tested and are in operation in the country.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  The estimated economic internal rates of return of seven indicative subprojects to be 
financed by the facility—two multimodal transit centers (Anand Vihar and Sarai Kale Khan in 
Delhi), three roads projects (Badli bypass and Sonepat and Jhajjar roads in Haryana), and 
water supply and sewerage projects (in Pataudi town in Haryana)—range from 12.7% to 64.8%, 
indicating sufficiently high economic return compared with the opportunity cost of capital.23 The 
financial internal rate of return for the multimodal transit centers in Anand Vihar and Sarai Kale 
Khan ranges from 10.1% to 11.6%, and for the water supply subproject in Pataudi it is 6.3%. 
The financial internal rates of return for all subprojects compare favorably to the weighted 
average cost of capital.24 As roads are not revenue-generating, the analysis focused on the 
capacity  of  the  investment  program  of  the  subborrower,  the  Public  Works  Department  of 
Haryana. Sensitivity analysis shows that the economic and financial internal rates of return are 
generally robust and relatively sensitive to changes in revenues. 
 
C.  Governance 
22.  The financial management and governance assessment reveals that there are no major 
issues with the accounting policies and procedures followed by NCRPB.25 NCRPB prepares 
accounts using accrual-based double-entry accounting as per the accepted Indian accounting 
standards, which are generally compatible with international accounting standards. NCRPB 
follows the Government of India's General Finance Rules (2005) and accounts are prepared in 
the formats specified by the Comptroller and Auditor General's Office. Strengthening of financial 
management  system  of  NCRPB  has  been  undertaken  with  the  support  of  ADB  technical 
assistance (footnote 15). Moreover, NCRPB has agreed to (i) undertake additional steps to 
achieve prudential norms of a financial intermediary; (ii) hire additional staff, among others, to 
strengthen project implementation (including financial management and procurement); and (iii) 
strengthen  project  approval  and  implementation  process  (footnote  10).  An  assessment  of 
procurement capacity and procedures of NCRPB and selected subborrowers reveal that ADB's 
key procurement principles of economy and efficiency, fairness, and transparency are adhered 
to. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with NCRPB. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in 
the facility administration manual (footnote 21). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
23.  The facility reduces infrastructure and funding constraints, which will lead to faster and 
more  inclusive  growth.  Some  sectors  directly  contribute  to  the  achievement  of  Millennium 
Development Goals, particularly water supply and sanitation. However, the facility contribution 
to poverty reduction is largely indirect. Long-term infrastructure development contributes to

economic growth which can have poverty reduction impacts, particularly in urban areas where 
most of the facility's subprojects will be undertaken. A subproject selection criterion allows the 
financing of subprojects which directly address urban poverty issues, including provision of 
water in unserved areas and slum improvement, among other things. The facility also provides 
assistance  to  Uttar  Pradesh  in  subproject  development.  Uttar  Pradesh,  with  lower  project 
development capacities, is also one of the states with higher poverty incidence, and so the 
facility's  subprojects  will  have  higher  benefits  to  the  poor.  Because  women  benefit  from 
subprojects and because they are disadvantaged by lower levels of education and literacy, the 
gender action plan ensures that (i) subproject details are disclosed to female beneficiaries, 
(ii) concerns of women are recorded and the design includes mitigation, (iii) subproject benefits 
positively impact women and benefits are equitable, and (iv) women are employed in subproject 
construction.26 
 
E.  Safeguards 
24.  The facility is classified under category FI for environment, involuntary resettlement, and 
indigenous peoples. Due diligence and review show that there are no anticipated significant 
adverse environmental impacts. Limited negative impacts during construction can readily be 
mitigated.  There  are  significant  positive  environmental  and  public  health  benefits  from 
subprojects. A subproject selection criterion ensures that involuntary resettlement impacts will 
be avoided or minimized; hence, anticipated impacts are limited. No impacts on indigenous 
peoples are anticipated. Environmental impacts during design and construction stages are 
readily addressed through mitigation measures. An ESMS is in place and an ESMS document 
has been prepared, which clarifies NCRPB's environmental and social policies and operational 
guidelines,  safeguards  screening,  categorization,  review  procedures,  and  oversight  during 
subproject  implementation.  The  ESMS  document  also  sets  out  a  plan  to  strengthen  the 
environmental and social organization structure and staffing, and performance monitoring and 
reporting procedures. The ESMS includes further development of institutional capacity within 
NCRPB  to  manage  environmental  and  social  issues.  The  ESMS  has  been  endorsed  by 
NCRPB.27 Disclosure of subproject safeguards documents are further described in the ESMS 
(footnote 22).

IV.  ASSURANCES  
26.  NCRPB  and  the  government  have  assured  ADB  that  facility  implementation  shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in  the  facility  administration  manual  (footnote  21)  and  loan  documents.  NCRPB  and  the 
government have given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, which are set forth in the 
framework financing agreement (footnote 10). Specific covenants agreed by NCRPB and the 
government  with  respect  to  individual  tranches  under  the  MFF  are  set  forth  in  the  loan 
agreement and guarantee agreement for the respective tranches. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
27.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount not exceeding $150,000,000 to the National Capital Region Planning Board, to be 
guaranteed by the Government of India, for the National Capital Region Urban Infrastructure 
Financing Facility from ADB's ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, and such 
other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the 
framework financing agreement presented to the Board.
